sys_metadata_link.payload:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><record_update table="x_431105_cand_ass_question_library"> <x_431105_cand_ass_question_library action="INSERT_OR_UPDATE"> <answers>Building intemational relationships whilst at school sets the foundations for intemational migration as adults. ‘The benefits of partnering with schools in different ‘countries were only experienced by the pupils at the schools.
Partnering with schools in different countries is particularly effective when the schools connect using virtual technologies.
‘The strongest impact of the partnerships was on the cultural awareness and expression, and social and civic ‘competences demonstrated by pupils.</answers> <assessment_state display_value="Preselection CBT">5165ad5897442110a4deb9dfe153af6f</assessment_state> <correct_answer>‘The strongest impact of the partnerships was on the cultural awareness and expression, and social and civic ‘competences demonstrated by pupils.</correct_answer> <default_max_value>8</default_max_value> <number>QLB0001021</number> <question>A new study on the impact of partnerships between schools in different countries has found that pupils - particularly at secondary level - significantly improved their skills, including cultural and social skills, IT and foreign languages. The impact of the partnerships was strongest on pupils who visited partner schools. Seven out of ten schools said that the partnerships had a strong to very strong impact on pupils' cultural awareness and expression as well as social and civic competences. This was followed by computer skills (54%) and communication in foreign languages (52%). The study also found that the scheme benefits teachers and schools within their local community. Teachers said partnering a foreign school improved their knowledge of other education systems and strengthened social skills, as well as helping their language skills.
Which of the following statements is correct?</question> <selection_criteria display_value="Verbal Reasoning">1a4e91d097442110a4deb9dfe153af4c</selection_criteria> <sys_created_by>admin</sys_created_by> <sys_created_on>2022-12-24 14:56:18</sys_created_on> <sys_id>e9b07d9497842110a4deb9dfe153af45</sys_id> <sys_mod_count>3</sys_mod_count> <sys_updated_by>admin</sys_updated_by> <sys_updated_on>2022-12-25 06:45:23</sys_updated_on> </x_431105_cand_ass_question_library> </record_update>

Partnering with schools in different countries is particularly effective when the schools connect using virtual technologies.

The impact of the partnerships was strongest on pupils who visited partner schools. Seven out of ten schools said that the partnerships had a strong to very strong impact on pupils' cultural awareness and expression as well as social and civic competences. This was followed by computer skills (54%) and communication in foreign languages (52%). The study also found that the scheme benefits teachers and schools within their local community. Teachers said partnering a foreign school improved their knowledge of other education systems and strengthened social skills, as well as helping their language skills.
